San Angelo Officials to Meet With Mobile Home Park Owners Monday

  • Facebook
  • linkedin
  • twitter
  • reddit
  • google+

By Matt McDaniel | Jul 18, 2014 5:22 pm CDT
Last Updated: Jul 19, 2014 10:08 am CDT

The City of San Angelo issued the following press release about the situation at Stardust Mobile Home Park on Friday afternoon, just after 4 p.m.

Water service at the Stardust Mobile Home Park will continue through the weekend to allow the property’s owner to seek remedies to a leaking sewer line and to give tenants more time to make necessary arrangements.

City officials and representatives of the park’s owner will meet Monday to discuss options. If an immediate and satisfactory remedy is unavailable, the City of San Angelo will pursue legal action to alleviate the public health threat. That process may involve interruption of water service to the park, located at 2501 Martin Luther King Blvd.

The sewer system failure has resulted in a flow of raw sewage from the property.

Park residents were initially notified in writing by City health officials that water service to the property would be shut off today to stop the flow of sewage. After observing this morning that the seepage had reduced and remained underground, City officials decided to delay that move to allow additional time for residents to make other accommodations and for the park’s owners to address the situation. The Water Utilities Department will monitor the leak throughout the weekend.

 The City’s Health Services Department has been in discussions with the Stardust’s ownership since a contained, underground leak was discovered more than two months ago. The Water Utilities Department on July 9 approved final engineering plans submitted by the park that same day to tie a new line into the City’s sewage system.

In recent days, the sewage began seeping from the ground. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality has been briefed and consulted on the situation.

Health Services Director Sandra Villarreal said the public health hazard could be exacerbated by summer heat, flying insects and possible runoff into the Concho River. City crews have treated the affected area with chlorine in an effort to minimize contamination.

The park’s management has suggested residents seek assistance from the Salvation Army and other charitable organizations. The City does not offer temporary housing programs.

“Knowing residents would be displaced, the decision to pursue an interruption of water service to the property is one we do not want to make,” Assistant City Manager Rick Weise said. “The City has worked in good faith with the park’s ownership to remedy the problem. But the situation has grown to the point that it poses a public health hazard.”

If water service were stopped, it would remain off until the sewer line leak is remediated.

Residents face the daunting challenge of finding new quarters if Monday's talks are not successful.
